entry.title: mid-year update
entry.content:
Happy summer.

It‚Äôs roughly half-time for this year and hence, besides planning to enjoy music at the F√™te de la musique, now is a good time to reflect on my 2023 goals.

Let‚Äôs annotate my personal objectives. For the details, I‚Äôll refer you to the relevant blog post:

  • üéµ learning the Ukulele
    • I would say I‚Äôm on a good path to achieve this goal
    • I can say I can play a few songs, I‚Äôm a long way to mastery but I will at least play for kids at the daycare
  • üñäÔ∏è write roughly a substantial article per month
    • I‚Äôm definitely late on this one. The Ukulele took most of my spare time.
  • üì∑ a photo-roll with around 30 photos I‚Äôm proud of
    • I think I have quite a few photos from my family trip to China. I haven‚Äôt taken the time to sort through them. Without much surprise, the photo-roll is gonna document time spent with my daughter.
  • üíª a number of improvements to the blog-engine:
    • I‚Äôm also on a good path to achieve this goal. KitchenSink now has been documented in depth, and recently got the support for hashtags. Yay #goals .
    • I also have a PoC working for the federation-mode for the explorer but it‚Äôs probably bitrotten already.
  • üëî work-wise I‚Äôd like Echoes to jump in adoption to move to the next phase
    • Not commenting on the particular strategy/situation here üòâ. Tech-wise I‚Äôve pushed quite a few changes and more to come as we fluidly adapt to load increases.

In summary, apart from the writing on this very blog, I‚Äôm doing quite ok on night-owl activities. I have enough draft material and ideas for a few articles already. What remains is time-budgetting.
entry.summary: Happy summer! reflecting on my yearly goals.

entry.content:
Happy new-year.

Having closed 2022 and now started 2023 for a few days already, I am happy to wish you an happy new year 2023.

Here are a number of personal goals I record, trying to set some goals

  • üéµ learning the Ukulele
    • my main motivator is to sing a few kids songs occasionally and during vacations with friends tes
  • üñäÔ∏è write roughly a substantial article per month (I judge 10 articles from 2022 to meet the bar)
  • üì∑ a photo-roll with around 30 photos I‚Äôm proud of
  • üíª a number of improvements to the blog-engine:
    • in-markdown keywords to increase the value of Kitchen-Sink as note-taking
    • federation-mode for the explorer (i.e., to connect other blogs)
  • üëî work-wise I‚Äôd like Echoes to jump in adoption to move to the next phase
    • I believe we already have a good offering but we‚Äôve quite a few ideas to provide even more features

entry.title: About me
entry.content:
Contacts

  • lucas[@]dicioccio[dot]fr

Experience

I‚Äôve been around quite some time and I have seen and taken a variety of roles. I‚Äôve gone through a PhD programme, enjoyed it a lot but really preferred the materialistic benefits of higher-paying jobs than what French Academia has to offer. I‚Äôve worked on small and extremely-large systems, microteams to mega-corp. I‚Äôve done research, development, and operational work and found an interest in each of these fields.

  • current First hire at Echoes
  • Architect at Veepee
  • #SRE at Google London
  • Early #engineer at Scaleway
  • #PhD Student at UPMC Sorbonne Universit√©s / Technicolor
  • Break-year at PurpleLabs (became Myriad Group)

Besides, you‚Äôll find a number of #talks, presentation, and document templates for tech leaders and SREs on my Talks page.

Personal

My name is Lucas DiCioccio. I prefer to define myself as a scientist/engineer generalist. However I lean and find creative ways to apply advanced techniques to software engineering. I am also a learning-dad and an hobbyist photographer.

Automated selfie

I now automatically generate a selfie sometimes when I update this website:

How to pronounce my last name

Apparently someone made a YouTube video to teach how to pronounce my last name:

  • how to pronounce DiCioccio
entry.summary: I am Lucas DiCioccio, a scientist and engineer. I apply modern techniques to engineering and lead #teams to deliver successful results.

entry.title: Talks and Docs
entry.content:
I am a bit more quiet now that I have a daughter and now that the pandemic started devastating the world but I‚Äôve done quite a few presentations in the past. I will probably blog more in the future. In addition I‚Äôve added a link of document templates that you may find useful.

If you feel interested in some #talks becoming articles (or, on the opposite and article becoming a talk), please enquire.

Haskell and Functional Programming

Most of my talks spree was while actively learning and applying Haskell to real-world problems (in a sense I still do but not in a professional context).

The Haskell Pyramid

summary A recurring talk I gave (and other people did as well) to explain why Haskell seems so mystic to bystanders. It sort of diffused and has inspired a few people to detail what further better than I would.

gist You can be productive in Haskell with ‚Äòsimple haskell‚Äô, but no-one is discussing ‚Äòsimple haskell‚Äô on the social networks.

related

  • not affiliated A reddit post asking what is the base of the pyramid
  • not affiliated a proposition of a Haskell pyramid
  • not affiliated a proposition for the bottom of the Haskell pyramid

links

  • google slides

Functional is a direction

gist: If you plot the programming languages on an X/Y graph with X as the quality of the local reasoning and Y the level of formalism you use. You‚Äôll notice that languages tend to appear and move to the upper-right direction ‚ÜóÔ∏è.

links

  • google slides

Haskell teachings applied to architecture

summary I am a software architect and I‚Äôve designed pretty big systems. Haskell‚Äôs closeness to mathematical abstractions are useful to think. For instance, the duality between sum-types and product-types is a duality you will find between producers and consumers services in large companies.

links

  • google slides

ProdAPI

summary Slides showing how ProdAPI modularizes a service application like in web-service architectures.

links

  • google slides
  • github

gRPC native

summary A talk I gave to introduce my gRPC library during Zurihac2020.

links

  • google slides
  • github

http2-client

summary A talk I gave to introduce my http2-client library at a Haskell-Paris Meetup.

links

  • google slides
  • github

Composing Web APIs with Servant

summary A talk I gave to introduce the amazing Servant library to write web-API and clients at a While42-London. It‚Äôs a bit lengthy as it tries to share my concept of ‚Äòcomposition‚Äô. That said, the visualizations/animations of how to match ‚Äòtypes together‚Äô in a Servant API can be helpful. I guess most of the content is still up to date (early 2022) because the Servant concept are rock solid.

links

  • google slides

An introduction to functional programming

summary A talk I gave at Veepee to explain FP basics. I got plenty of appraisal from colleagues at the time, so I guess it is a decently-good starting material to get a feeling of things like immutability , map and fold.

links

  • google slides

Les monades en comptant sur ses doigts

summary A monad-tutorial I gave at at Haskell-Paris meetup. Only the title of this talk is in French.

links

  • google slides

MiniZinc and Constraint-Programming

I have fallen in love with modeling and optimizing engineering (but not only) problems. You will likely see Alloy-content pop up at some point as well. #optimization

Constraint-Programming with MiniZinc

summary A constraint-programming introduction I gave for VPTech. We also solve the cabbage-goat-wolf problem in MiniZinc.

related

  • not affiliated solving river crossing puzzles , my talk inspired Raimondas Sasnauskas to write down the solution to the cabbage-goat-wolf problem I used towards the later parts of the talk. His article is a good tutorial.

links

  • google slides
  • youtube recording

Architecture and Site-Reliability Engineering

I was an #SRE in one of the most hectic team at Google. Add this my especially-bad luck and one could say I‚Äôve handled quite a lot of incidents. Then I‚Äôve been an Architect in a pretty large company with a lot of complex business processes, a good amount of old and poorly-understood code where challenges abund.

Aborder la production comme un SRE üá´üá∑

summary Trying to convey what the SRE approach is. When I gave this talk, few people were interested in the term SRE. In France we alas mostly renamed Devops but here in this recording in French I explain what the SRE approach and mindset is in the place I‚Äôve experienced it.

links

  • google slides
  • youtube recording

Post-Mortem Template

A good post-mortem takes time to write but it‚Äôs a goldmine of information. I‚Äôve written this template after a request from a friend who had trouble going past the ‚Äòincident report‚Äô that was only scratching the surface. So I wrote a template of Post-Mortem with some text of a pseudo story of things that went wrong.

links

  • google doc

Design-Doc Template

A template of Design-Doc. A number of sections may be superfluous depending on how fast. But what is key (besides motivating the problem you are trying to solve) is to properly define the axes of analysis from the proper solution-analysis.

links

  • google doc

Vacat Page Template

A Vacat Page is a page intentionally left blank. Good vacat pages are hard to find. I‚Äôve taken the freedom to plagiarize a vacat page from a book I paid 90euros.

links

  • vacat page template
entry.summary: A list of slides (with recording links when available) for presentations I gave. Also some template documents for architecture/devops.
